_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Applicable building, electrical, and plumbing codes. This facility complies with the Iowa Fertilizer Law.
_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: We utilize those portions of these codes which are deemed applicable by the jurisdictional authority
_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vandalism (methamphetamines). Provisions have been made to install a protective barrier around the perimeter of the plant to reduce the potential for vehicular damage.
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Flow Limiters=what in the trade is called an excess flow valve. Breakaway couplers have been installed at the risers and a remote emergency shut-off valve has been installed ath the storage tank.
_prev_prog_2.MS_OtherType: Regular plant inspection/Routine preventive maintenance & repair
_prev_prog_2.TR_OtherType: NH3 Specialist Training for Select employees throughout the company
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Pumps, pump seals, pipes and plumbing, valves, electrical equipment, and safety equipment. The breakaway couplers, pressure relief valves, and hoses are also inspected and replaced as necessary.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response
for Heartland Co-op, Melbourne, Iowa

It is the policy of Heartland Co-op to adhere to all applicable Federal, State, and local regulations. If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to call 911 and request emergency responders be dispatched to an anhydrous ammonia release.  Incidental to the 911 call, the County Emergency Coordinator will be contacted as well as the LEPC (if different from the County Emergency Coordinator).

While we have planned for an emergency, it is acknowledged that a real emergency will be unexpected and may very well be much different and cannot be ensured to duplicate what may have be planned. In reality, the situation that develops may not happen in the manner in which it has been planned. In that event, what may have been planned will serve only as a guideline to follow.

The Emergency Action Plan for this facility describes certain procedures that are intended to minimize the hazards associated with human health and the environment from fires, explosions, the sudden and unexpected release of chemicals (i.e., Anhydrous Ammonia), tornadoes, bomb threats or other accidents or acts of God which might occur on our premises.

The primary emergency coordinator for the Melbourne, Iowa location is the Location Manager. His work and 24-hour emergency response telephone numbers are provided in the Registration Section of this document. In addition, the following individuals (with associated work and 24-hour emergency response telephone numbers) are to be contacted in order:
Phil Gowdy, location manager
Work:    641.482.3206
Evening:   641.753.6333

Deanna Damman
Work:     641.482.3206
Evening:   641.482.3536


DESCRIPTION OF THE ANHYDROUS AMMONIA STORAGE/DISTRIBUTION PLANT AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED AT HEARTLAND 
CO-OP, MELBOURNE, IOWA:
This facility is a bulk anhydrous ammonia storage and distribution plant. The anhydrous ammonia that is stored at  this facility is distributed to

agricultural crop producers in the surrounding area who utilize the anhydrous ammonia for crop nutrient purposes. 

The system consists of one (1)  26,000-gallon storage tank with associated piping, valves, liquid pump(s), and other miscellaneous equipment. The anhydrous ammonia plant is only operated on a seasonal basis (Spring and Fall). Full-time equivalent employee numbers were computed on that basis. At a maximum, the plant operates a total of three months (1/4 of the year). The FTEs for this company location is one (1).
 
GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:
This facility complies with EPA's accident prevention rule and all applicable State and local codes and regulations. 

In addition the company has specific operating procedures in place intended to minimize the potential for an accidental (and potentially catastrophic) release of anhydrous ammonia. Finally, Heartland Co-op has extended to the local fire department the opportunity to visit our anhydrous ammonia plant, to participate in mock emergency simulation training, and to avail themselves of specific anhydrous ammonia health hazard information and training provided by the company.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:
Heartland Co-op, formerly Farmers Cooperative Exchange, Melbourne, Iowa has never had an accident involving anhydrous ammonia that caused death, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations or sheltering in place.

THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:
Heartland Co-op is included in this Counties Annex P.  The company does not have it¿s own emergency response plan.  In the event of an emergency involving our anhydrous ammonia system, it is the policy of Heartland Co-op to immediately notify the local fire department and the County Emergency Coordinator (often also the LEPC contact) to request that they respond to the emergency.  In the unlikely event that the local fire department is unable to adequately respond to an emergency at this locatio

n, the hazmat team with whom this fire department has a reciprocal agreement will be summoned.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:
The plan is to minimize those hazards to human health and to the environment that are associated with accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. Employees working at the bulk storage plant make routine observations prior to and during transfer operations of the anhydrous ammonia from the storage vessel(s) to nurse tanks. In so doing, they are able to detect problems before they arise. This routine inspection identifies any portion of the system which may be under stress or about to fail. Repairs can be made before they become problematic. Employees are annually trained to recognize the hazards associated with storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia. In addition to annual training for employees who have been on the job for a number of years, the company conducts training for new hires. This training includes classroom instruction, on-site training at the plant, and follow-up observation to determine their individual comprehension and understanding of the new hire. Finally, the company routinely invites local fire department personnel to visit the site. In the event that the local fire department requests assistance in training its employees on anhydrous ammonia, the company cooperates fully in their endeavors.
